description: A scientist sits astride the neck of a large dinosaur skeleton, holding its skull like reins, while another scientist on the ground argues with him. The conflict centers on who claimed a specific part of the fossil second, rather than first, introducing an element of absurd one-upmanship to the process of paleontological discovery. The scene presents a surreal view of academic rivalry, where physical positioning on the ancient remains and the timing of arbitrary claims become paramount.
caption: “I assume you’re being facetious, Andrews. … I distinctly yelled ‘second!’ before you did.”
